Therefore, approving this Resolution is now the challenge for this Parliament, without a doubt.
But let the Commission's challenge be met if, indeed, Commissioner, you wish to prevent the South of the Union, which does exist, from continuing to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for granting me the floor. I am addressing Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have been following you with great interest and deep respect for a long time, since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and dearly loved, namely Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that now you have me absolutely astonished.

I am surprised for two reasons, firstly, because you have shown contempt towards the group I belong to, the Non-Attached Members' Group, not deeming us worthy of a single minute of your time to come and share your political proposals with us.
We represent many European citizens, and you have shown contempt for all our voters.
Secondly, due to the fragility of its political project, and the poverty of its political proposals in the document "Political Guidelines for the Next Commission."
some proposals that do not even begin to reflect the positions you have upheld throughout your own term as President of the Commission.
In this regard, I have been surprised that issues such as energy, which have been well addressed throughout your term, now, as you present your proposals to us,

Madam Commissioner, you concluded your remarks by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began by saying that you had already taken all the necessary measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, to correct is the mark of wisdom.
And that is a Spanish saying that could be very aptly applied to the case that concerns us today.

The dairy sector has been suffering for months from one of the most severe crises in its history. Despite this, due to the refusal to yield, whether from you, the European Commission, or certain governments, including what appears to be my own, the Spanish government, which denies reversing the decisions of the Health Check of the CAP, the Common Agricultural Policy.
These decisions were made without considering the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was closed.
It seems that the Member States either did not want to or could not see the storm that was brewing at the time.
The reform became outdated in a short time due to the significant shift in the market, a change that demonstrates the sector's complete vulnerability to price volatility.

That major producers such as France and Germany, countries that achieved, in absolute terms, the largest increase in their national production quotas under that agreement, are now the ones calling for a review of the check-up's decisions, gives much cause for thought.

In my understanding, the Member States were mistaken and should have listened more attentively to the voices, mine included, that called for postponing any definitive decision on the future of the sector until 2011.
A shame they didn't listen to us.
You will listen. Do it now.
Mr. President, this Parliament is the Palace of Chimeras, it is the Palace of Dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, give us the encouragement and strength to continue thriving and to build a strong Europe, and above all, a federal Europe.
Only in this way, only in this way, would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs to the fathers of Europe, whose work brought us all here.

Mr. President, having overcome the concern generated by the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, it is time, in my view, to consider how to address nationalist attitudes in the future, which so hinder European construction.
My idea is that these obstructions cannot come without cost.
With a clear mind, it is time to consider the possible measures to be taken in the days and years ahead.
This modest representative wishes for a future President of the Council who is a man, or better yet, a woman, convinced of European federalism, capable of steering the...
euro, which is located in the Schengen area and is identified and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
In other words, on behalf of the Commission, I would have nothing more to add, but I already had my speech prepared on behalf of the Socialist Group.

The breakdown of the constitutional order in Honduras ends two decades without coups in Latin America and sets a perverse precedent for other countries, especially the weakest ones, as is now the case with Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and silent in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting President Arias' mediation, in line with the position adopted unanimously by the OAS with the backing of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president, Michelete, has breached the recently reached agreements, mocking the international community and preventing, among other measures, the return of the duly elected president, Mr. Celaya, to office.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the elections scheduled for November twenty-ninth suffers from a lack of legitimacy from its inception, and its results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would commit a serious error if it were to send a delegation to observe the elections, as this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament is renowned as a guardian of freedom, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for human rights.
As Václav Havel stated this morning, there cannot be two weights or two measures.

We are all democrats here and, consequently, freedom fighters. And therefore, whether we speak of Cuba, China, North Korea, or now Honduras, our discourse must be firm against those who suppress liberty.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preference.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup plotters or dictators, only freedom-killers and oppressors.

Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change, and as a result, a very dangerous precedent will have been set. The doctrine of the "good," temporary, and not-too-cruel coup will have prevailed.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the members of the ENVI Committee and its Chair, Mr. Leinen, for the work they have done to enable us to have a Resolution such as the one we have and which we must approve unequivocally.
We cannot be content with talking about having enough with sectoral agreements, because talking about a patchwork agreement is already admitting a part of the failure.
We have decided to adopt this Resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
A more explicit one is to prevent climate change with concrete proposals for emissions reduction and with a commitment to funding, and aiming for a binding agreement, I say, not a patchwork.

and two latent aspirations: one, to start sooner rather than later to work towards a common energy policy, as we once endowed ourselves with a common agricultural policy because it was necessary; and the other, of course, which is also included, is to regain the trust of citizens in politics and politicians, of which we have more than enough in Europe.
In that regard, the success of the Summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
Therefore, I encourage the acting President of the Council to maintain his optimism, to apply pressure and negotiate as much as possible to bring others on board for this success.

I do not know if the leaders of this multipolar world wish to be called into question by history for their inability to reach a binding agreement, but I, as a representative, and I believe all representatives of the people, cannot be called into question by history for failing to secure the binding commitment we have to humanity in Copenhagen to avert climate change.

There is no doubt today about the European Union's commitment to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Treaty, the Stockholm Program, we will continue to make progress in this area of freedom, justice, and security, which is so necessary.

However, in my view, this struggle has been based on mutual trust among member states. It is high time, with the opportunities provided by the Lisbon Treaty, to harmonize national legislations towards the non-prescription of terrorist offenses, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has happened, happens, and may continue to happen, to the detriment of terrorism victims, who see how those who murdered their loved ones are treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore call on this Parliament to promote or adopt the European Charter of Victims' Rights in Terrorism, based on the defense of memory.
Mr. President, I would like, first of all, to congratulate Mrs. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role played by the CAP in addressing the international food supply needs.
